subject: Re: [junit] Testing non-public classes in different packages
msgSnippet: If the package is signed, then there might be an issue.  But there is nothing prohibiting you from writing you test class inside the package of the class you
messageBody:
If the package is signed, then there might be an issue. But there is
nothing prohibiting you from writing you test class inside the package
of the class you are testing. Just use the same directory structure.

Big Mike

On Wed, Jul 22, 2009 at 3:19 AM,
maier.georg@...<maier.georg@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I've got a question concerning tests on non-public classes. Is there any possibility to test these classes if they are located in a different package? I'm thinking of something equal to setAccessible(true) for functions. Now I know that this won't work with classes as they are not derived from AccessibleObject.
> To load the class outside the package I use something like
>
> Class myClass = Class.forName("reflection.classes.MyClass");
>
> But if I try
>
> Object instance = myClass.newInstance();
>
> I get an IllegalAccessException.
>
> Anyone knows about this?
> Thanks!
